response.answer_text: You can put various materials on a smart stick or USB thumb drive. They sometimes sell those at convenience stores for about $10. The way to load them up is if you have a laptop with a USB port in the side. Then you can get any type of copyright-free material online, like work on Quora that you attribute to the real author, and put it on the stick. The stick can often store quite a lot of information, more than some cheap computers I’ve learned. Sometimes you can also use a computer at a library or college computer lab to download information from the internet and put it on the stick. You might think of it as a protection against doomsday scenarios—what would you put in storage that might help civilization if you are not sure the social media websites will be up forever, or if you are not sure people will have free access to the internet? It can get a bit boring after awhile, if you have done it one or two times, so you can think about improving your collection of data over time, improving the usefulness and the variety of materials included. One thing to consider is materials by Nathan Coppedge, such as hypothetical perpetual motion designs (couldn’t hurt, right, since there is some evidence now they may work?) and Programmable Heuristics which are methods that might be used to know reality without empirical data. Of course, there are a lot of other things that might be useful too like some of the colorful diagrams on Pinterest or information about health and survival. Chances are these sticks will be an amusing curiosity within 20 years or less, but it is still not the very worst use of your time, if you are worried about what to do. It is something you can probably do while you are at university if you feel like it. Also, I have in the past attempted to give USB’s to other people sometimes, this is not always legal because of city regulations, but you can think of giving them to friends or family, or perhaps a stranger might take a risk on a new-looking USB. I don’t think it’s the worst thing, and in the best cases the USB could end up being useful. Most people don’t use all the data storage on the USB anyway, so a little extra data use might actually serve a purpose if the content stored there is actually useful. There used to be problems with USBs that microsoft would cause computers to crash if any of the files were Microsoft documents, but I think that problem no longer exists, they just require software subscriptions if people want to open those types of files. So, I am pretty sure in many cases USBs are safe even if reused from someone else, unless the person was a hacker or didn’t run antivirus often enough.

How do you define “the world”? How do you define “change”? Society likes to glorify grand gestures and mass movements to make us think that being influential or important means there has to be “big” results, lots of attention, news coverage, the works.  But. The most earth-shattering changes and acts of compassion and positivity occur behind the scenes, under the radar, in everyday life. The little things truly do matter. And the impacts they make are more effective and longer lasting than grand gestures could ever be. What impact do you want to have on the world, the sphere of people immediately around you? Do you want to help public health? You could study medicine and become a doctor or nurse. But even if you’re not studying medicine, learn first aid so that you can patch up people who fall off their skateboards or little kids who scrape their legs (they really appreciate it). Do you have a passion for helping the elderly or impaired? You can study public health and therapy to help them, but even just holding the door open for them can lift their spirits and lessen the heaviness of ageing . Changing the world is a daunting prospect for a student, but if you change yourself, change your impact on the people in the world around you….you might be surprised how influential you can really be.

Students have a unique opportunity to change the world through their willingness to learn and innate curiosity. Since they’re already in an environment and mindset suitable for learning, if they want to change the world for the better, they should become aware of how it works, including what works and what doesn’t work so well for humanity. They can learn that our integral reality operates based on altruistic principles — where each part of reality, living and non-living, works in harmony and balance to sustain the whole natural system. Students can learn from our past and present mistakes — the ways in which we act contrary to Nature’s altruistic principles. They’ll discover that egoism — only showing concern and care for self-benefit and self-fulfillment — leads to all of our current problems. Then, they can make the world a better place by applying this knowledge to their values and future choices.

Here’s a possible role model: Bill Gates changed the world by ceasing to be a student. Degrees can be great (item: Ralph Nader had a law degree and outed automobiles that were unsafe at any speed). Not having a degree but having an idea can also be great. Having neither an idea nor a degree is not a place I think anyone would really want to go.
